title: Vitamin C megadosage - Wikipedia
cleaned_text: Vitamin C megadosage |This article is part of |[Alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) Vitamin C megadosage is a term describing the consumption or injection of [vitamin C](/wiki/Vitamin_C) (ascorbic acid) in [doses](/wiki/Dose_(biochemistry)) well beyond the current United States [Recommended Dietary Allowance](/wiki/Recommended_Dietary_Allowance) of 90 milligrams per day, and often well beyond the [tolerable upper intake level](/wiki/Tolerable_upper_intake_level) of 2,000 milligrams per day. [[1]](#cite_note-DRItext-1) There is no scientific evidence that vitamin C megadosage helps to cure or prevent cancer, the common cold, or some other medical conditions. [[2]](#cite_note-ACS-2) [[3]](#cite_note-:0-3) Historical advocates of vitamin C megadosage include [Linus Pauling](/wiki/Linus_Pauling), who won the [Nobel Prize in Chemistry](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry) in 1954. Pauling argued that because humans lack a functional form of [L-gulonolactone oxidase](/wiki/L-gulonolactone_oxidase), an enzyme required to make vitamin C that is functional in most other mammals, plants, insects, and other life forms, humans have developed a number of adaptations to cope with the relative deficiency. These adaptations, he argued, ultimately shortened lifespan but could be reversed or mitigated by supplementing humans with the hypothetical amount of vitamin C that would have been produced in the body if the enzyme were working. Vitamin C megadoses are claimed by [alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) advocates including [Matthias Rath](/wiki/Matthias_Rath) and [Patrick Holford](/wiki/Patrick_Holford) to have preventive and curative effects on diseases such as [cancer](/wiki/Cancer) and [AIDS](/wiki/Acquired_immunodeficiency_syndrome), [[4]](#cite_note-4) [[5]](#cite_note-5) but the available scientific evidence does not support these claims. [[3]](#cite_note-:0-3) Some trials show some effect in combination with other therapies, but this does not imply vitamin C megadoses in themselves have any therapeutic effect. [[6]](#cite_note-6) Background[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C_megadosage&action=edit§ion=1)] Vitamin C is an essential nutrient used in the [production](/wiki/Biosynthesis) of [collagen](/wiki/Collagen) and other biomolecules, and for the prevention of [scurvy](/wiki/Scurvy). [[7]](#cite_note-Gropper-7) It is also an [antioxidant](/wiki/Antioxidant), which has led to its endorsement by some researchers as a complementary therapy for improving [quality of life](/wiki/Quality_of_life). [[8]](#cite_note-pmid17297243-8) Certain animal species, including the [haplorhine (which include [humans](/wiki/Humans)), [[9]](#cite_note-pmid5275366-9) [[10]](#cite_note-10) members of of rodents (including [guinea pigs](/wiki/Guinea_pigs) and [capybaras](/wiki/Capybaras)), [[11]](#cite_note-11) most species of bats, [[12]](#cite_note-12) many [passerine](/wiki/Passerine) birds, [[13]](#cite_note-Martinez_del_Rio_1997-13) and about 96% of fish (the [teleosts](/wiki/Teleosts)), [[13]](#cite_note-Martinez_del_Rio_1997-13) cannot synthesize vitamin C internally and must therefore rely on external sources, typically obtained from food. For humans, the [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization) recommends a daily intake of 45 mg/day of vitamin C for healthy adults, and 25-30 mg/day in infants. [[14]](#cite_note-14) Since its discovery, vitamin C has been considered almost a [panacea](/wiki/Panacea_(medicine)) by some, [[15]](#cite_note-15) although this led to suspicions of it being overhyped by others. [[16]](#cite_note-16) Vitamin C has long been promoted in [alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) as a treatment for the [common cold](/wiki/Common_cold), [cancer](/wiki/Cancer), [polio](/wiki/Polio), and various other illnesses. The evidence for these claims is mixed. Since the 1930s, when it first became available in pure form, some physicians have experimented with higher-than-recommended vitamin C consumption or injection. [[17]](#cite_note-UMM-17) [Orthomolecular](/wiki/Orthomolecular_medicine)-based megadose recommendations for vitamin C are based mainly on theoretical speculation and [observational studies](/wiki/Observational_studies), such as those published by [Fred R. Klenner](/wiki/Fred_R._Klenner) from the 1940s through the 1970s. There is a strong advocacy movement for very high doses of vitamin C, yet there is an absence of large-scale, formal trials in the 10 to 200+ grams per day range. The single repeatable [side effect](/wiki/Side_effect) of oral megadose vitamin C is a mild [laxative](/wiki/Laxative) effect if the practitioner attempts to consume too much too quickly. In the United States and Canada, a [tolerable upper intake level](/wiki/Tolerable_upper_intake_level) (UL) was set at 2,000 mg/day, citing this mild laxative effect as the reason for establishing the UL. [[1]](#cite_note-DRItext-1) However, the [European Food Safety Authority](/wiki/European_Food_Safety_Authority) (EFSA) reviewed the safety question in 2006 and reached the conclusion that there was not sufficient evidence to set a UL for vitamin C. [[18]](#cite_note-18) The Japan National Institute of Health and Nutrition reviewed the same question in 2010 and also reached the conclusion that there was not sufficient evidence to set a UL. [[19]](#cite_note-JapanDRI-19) About 70-90% of vitamin C is absorbed by the body when taken orally at normal levels (30-180 mg daily). Only about 50% is absorbed from daily doses of 1 gram (1,000 mg). Even oral administration of megadoses of 3g every four hours cannot raise blood concentration above 220 micromol/L. [[20]](#cite_note-20) Relative deficiency hypothesis[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C_megadosage&action=edit§ion=2)] Humans and other species that cannot synthesize their own vitamin C carry a mutated and ineffective form of the enzyme [L-gulonolactone oxidase](/wiki/L-gulonolactone_oxidase), the fourth and last step in the ascorbate-producing machinery. In the anthropoids lineage, this mutation likely occurred 40 to 25 million years ago.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] The three surviving enzymes continue to produce the precursors to vitamin C, but the absence of the fourth enzyme means the process is never completed, and the body ultimately disassembles the precursors. In the 1960s, the [Nobel-Prize](/wiki/Nobel_Prize)-winning chemist [Linus Pauling](/wiki/Linus_Pauling), after contact with [Irwin Stone](/wiki/Irwin_Stone), [[21]](#cite_note-21) began actively promoting vitamin C as a means to greatly improve human health and resistance to disease. His book How to Live Longer and Feel Better was a bestseller and advocated taking more than 10 grams per day orally, thus approaching the amounts released by the liver directly into the circulation in other mammals: an adult [goat](/wiki/Goat), a typical example of a vitamin C-producing animal, will manufacture more than 13,000 mg of vitamin C per day in normal health and much more when stressed.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] [Matthias Rath](/wiki/Matthias_Rath) is a controversial German physician who worked with and published two articles discussing the possible relationship between [lipoprotein](/wiki/Lipoprotein) and vitamin C with Pauling. [[22]](#cite_note-pmid2147514-22) [[23]](#cite_note-pmid2143582-23) He is an active proponent and publicist for high-dose vitamin C. Pauling's and Rath's extended theory states that deaths from scurvy in humans during the [Pleistocene](/wiki/Pleistocene), when vitamin C was scarce, selected for individuals who could repair arteries with a layer of [cholesterol](/wiki/Cholesterol) provided by lipoprotein(a), a lipoprotein found in vitamin C-deficient species. [[24]](#cite_note-Rath,_Pauling_1992-24) Stone [[25]](#cite_note-25) and Pauling [[9]](#cite_note-pmid5275366-9) believed that the optimum daily requirement of vitamin C is around 2,300 milligrams for a human requiring 2,500 [kcal](/wiki/Calorie) per day. For comparison, the FDA's recommended daily allowance of vitamin C is only 90 milligrams. [[1]](#cite_note-DRItext-1) Adverse effects[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C_megadosage&action=edit§ion=3)] Although sometimes considered free of toxicity, there are in fact known side effects from vitamin C intake, and it has been suggested that intravenous injections should require "a medical environment and trained professionals." [[26]](#cite_note-Verrax-26) For example, a genetic condition that results in inadequate levels of the enzyme [glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase](/wiki/Glucose-6-phosphate_dehydrogenase) (G6PD) can cause affected people to develop [hemolytic anemia](/wiki/Hemolytic_anemia) after using intravenous vitamin C treatment. [[27]](#cite_note-27) The G6PD deficiency test is a common laboratory test. Because [oxalic acid](/wiki/Oxalic_acid) is produced during metabolism of vitamin C, [hyperoxaluria](/wiki/Hyperoxaluria) can be caused by intravenous administration of ascorbic acid. [[26]](#cite_note-Verrax-26) Vitamin C administration may also acidify the [urine](/wiki/Urine) and could promote the [precipitation](/wiki/Precipitate) of [kidney stones](/wiki/Kidney_stone) or drugs in the urine. [[26]](#cite_note-Verrax-26) Although vitamin C can be well tolerated at doses well above what government organizations recommend, [adverse effects](/wiki/Adverse_effect) can occur at doses above 3 grams per day. The common "threshold" side effect of megadoses is [diarrhea](/wiki/Diarrhea). Other possible adverse effects include iron overload, reduced absorption of [vitamin B12](/wiki/Vitamin_B12) and copper, increased oxygen demand, and [acid erosion](/wiki/Acid_erosion) of the teeth when chewing vitamin C tablets. [[1]](#cite_note-DRItext-1) In addition, one case has been noted of a woman who received a kidney transplant followed by high-dose vitamin C and died soon afterwards as a result of [calcium oxalate](/wiki/Calcium_oxalate) deposits that destroyed her new kidney. Her doctors concluded that high-dose vitamin C therapy should be avoided in patients with [kidney failure](/wiki/Kidney_failure). [[28]](#cite_note-28) Overdose[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C_megadosage&action=edit§ion=4)] As discussed previously, vitamin C generally exhibits low toxicity. The [LD50](/wiki/Median_lethal_dose) (the dose that will kill 50% of a population) is generally accepted to be 11,900 milligrams (11.9 grams) per kilogram in rat populations. [[29]](#cite_note-29) The American Association of Poison Control Centers has reported zero deaths from vitamin C toxicity[ [when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items)]. [[30]](#cite_note-30) Interactions[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C_megadosage&action=edit§ion=5)] Pharmaceuticals designed to reduce stomach acid, such as the [proton-pump inhibitors](/wiki/Proton_pump_inhibitor) (PPIs), are among the most widely sold drugs in the world. One PPI, [omeprazole](/wiki/Omeprazole) (Prilosec), has been found to lower the bioavailability of vitamin C by 12% after 28 days of treatment, independent of dietary intake. The probable mechanism of vitamin C reduction, intragastric pH elevated into alkalinity, would apply to all other PPI drugs, though not necessarily to doses of PPIs low enough to keep the stomach slightly acidic. [[31]](#cite_note-31) In another study, 40 mg/day of omeprazole lowered the fasting gastric vitamin C levels from 3.8 to 0.7 µg/mL. [[32]](#cite_note-32) [Aspirin](/wiki/Aspirin) may also inhibit the absorption of vitamin C. [[33]](#cite_note-33) [[34]](#cite_note-34) Regulation[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C_megadosage&action=edit§ion=6)] There are regulations in most countries that limit the claims regarding treatment of disease that can be placed on food and dietary supplement product labels. For example, claims of therapeutic effect with respect to the treatment of any medical condition or disease are prohibited by the United States [Food and Drug Administration](/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration) even if the substance in question has gone through well conducted clinical trials with positive outcomes. Claims are limited to "structure and function" phrasing (like "helps maintain a healthy immune system") and the following notice is mandatory on food and dietary supplement product labels that make these types of health claims: These statements have not been evaluated by the Food and Drug Administration. This product is not intended to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any disease. [[35]](#cite_note-35) Research[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C_megadosage&action=edit§ion=7)] Cancer[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C_megadosage&action=edit§ion=8)] The use of vitamin C in high doses as a treatment for cancer was promoted by [Linus Pauling](/wiki/Linus_Pauling), based on a 1976 study published with [Ewan Cameron](/wiki/Ewan_Cameron_(physician)) which reported intravenous vitamin C significantly increased lifespans of patients with advanced cancer. [[36]](#cite_note-PNAS1976-36) [[2]](#cite_note-ACS-2) This trial was criticized by the [National Cancer Institute](/wiki/National_Cancer_Institute) for being designed poorly, and three subsequent trials conducted at the [Mayo Clinic](/wiki/Mayo_Clinic) could not replicate the results. [[2]](#cite_note-ACS-2) [[37]](#cite_note-Cabanillas-37) Preliminary clinical trials in humans have shown that it is unlikely to be a "miracle pill" for cancer and more research is necessary before any definitive conclusions about efficacy can be reached. [[26]](#cite_note-Verrax-26) A 2010 review of 33 years of research on vitamin C to treat cancer stated "we have to conclude that we still do not know whether Vitamin C has any clinically significant antitumor activity. Nor do we know which histological types of cancers, if any, are susceptible to this agent. Finally, we don't know what the recommended dose of Vitamin C is, if there is indeed such a dose, that can produce an anti-tumor response." [[37]](#cite_note-Cabanillas-37) The [American Cancer Society](/wiki/American_Cancer_Society) has stated, "Although high doses of vitamin C have been suggested as a cancer treatment, the available evidence from clinical trials has not shown any benefit." [[2]](#cite_note-ACS-2) Burns[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C_megadosage&action=edit§ion=9)] One clinical trial used high intravenous doses of vitamin C (66 mg/kg/hour for 24 hours, for a total dose of around 110 grams) after severe burn injury, [[38]](#cite_note-Berger-38) but despite being described as promising, it has not been [replicated](/wiki/Replication_(scientific_method)) by independent institutions and thus is not a widely accepted treatment. [[39]](#cite_note-39) Based on that study, the American Burn Association (ABA) considers high-dose ascorbic acid an option to be considered for adjuvant therapy in addition to the more accepted standard treatments. [[40]](#cite_note-ABA-40) Cardiac effects[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C_megadosage&action=edit§ion=10)] [Atrial fibrillation](/wiki/Atrial_fibrillation) (AF) is a rhythm disturbance associated with [oxidative stress](/wiki/Oxidative_stress). Four meta-analyses have concluded that there is strong evidence that consuming 1-2 g/day of vitamin C before and after cardiac operations can decrease the risk of post-operative AF. [[41]](#cite_note-Baker2016-41) [[42]](#cite_note-Polymeropoulos2016-42) [[43]](#cite_note-Hu2017-43) [[44]](#cite_note-Hemila2017-44) However, five randomized studies did not find any such benefit in the United States, so that the benefit was restricted to less wealthy countries. [[44]](#cite_note-Hemila2017-44) [[45]](#cite_note-Hemila2017b-45) Exercise-induced bronchoconstriction[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C_megadosage&action=edit§ion=11)] [Exercise-induced bronchoconstriction](/wiki/Exercise-induced_bronchoconstriction) (EIB) indicates acute narrowing of the airways as a result of vigorous exercise. EIB seems to be caused by the loss of water caused by increased ventilation, which may lead to the release of mediators such as histamine, prostaglandins, and leukotrienes, all of which cause bronchoconstriction. Vitamin C participates in the metabolism of these mediators and might thereby influence EIB. [[46]](#cite_note-Hemila2014-46) A meta-analysis showed that 0.5 to 2 g/day of vitamin C before exercise decreased EIB by half. [[47]](#cite_note-Hemila2013-47) Endothelial function[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C_megadosage&action=edit§ion=12)] A meta-analysis showed a significant positive effect of vitamin C on [endothelial](/wiki/Endothelium) function. Benefit was found of vitamin C in doses ranging from 0.5 to 4 g/day, whereas lower doses from 0.09 to 0.5 g/day were not effective. No effect on endothelial function was seen in healthy volunteers or healthy smokers. [[48]](#cite_note-Ashor2014-48) Common cold[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C_megadosage&action=edit§ion=13)] A frequently cited meta-analysis calculated that various doses of vitamin C (daily doses under 0.2 grams were excluded) do not prevent the [common cold](/wiki/Common_cold) in the general community, although 0.25 to 1 g/day of vitamin C halved the incidence of colds in people under heavy short-term physical stress. [[49]](#cite_note-Hemila2013b-49) Another meta-analysis calculated that, in children, 1-2 g/day vitamin C shortened the duration of colds by 18%, and in adults 1-4 g/day vitamin C shortened the duration of colds by 8%. [[49]](#cite_note-Hemila2013b-49) There is evidence of linear dose-dependency in the effect of vitamin C on common cold duration up to 6-8 g/day. [[50]](#cite_note-Hemila2017c-50)[ [jargon](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style#Technical_language)] As noted above, there is an absence of large-scale, formal trials in the 10 to 200+ grams per day range, so no information is available for these higher dosages. Additionally, the cited studies of larger daily doses of vitamin C do not take into account the fast excretion rate of vitamin C at gram-level doses, which makes it necessary to give the total daily amount in smaller, more frequent doses to maintain higher plasma levels. [[51]](#cite_note-51) As of 2014, at least 16 studies had found that vitamin C supplements did not prevent the common cold and had minimal effect at best in shortening cold lengths.
